a.aria-label: Contact Us - Contact Us - Staff Directory

span.a: You are currently on this page - Coronavirus Updates

td.a: March 15, 2020 - K-12 FAQ from Gov. Evers Office

td.h3: Information from District Administrator Teri Maney with Updated Calendar
td.p: We are in a time of information overload, which is very confusing. Stay at home orders, economic reopening phases and school activities seem to be guided under the same resolutions and guidelines … and yet they are not. We are in a constantly moving health and economic situation that has affected every one of us and our daily lives.

Per the current state order, schools and their facilities remain closed until June 30, 2020. Even if the Safer at Home requirements are lifted on May 26, that does not automatically mean schools and their facilities are open for business. This includes community use such as unlocking the fitness center or holding in-person gatherings on school grounds.

I am very in tune with the Wisconsin Governor's Office and messaging in cooperation with the Department of Health Services and Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction. My promise to you is that as soon as we have accurate information, it will be shared through Three Lakes School District messaging.

For now, we are planning the next phase of remote learning, which will include several teacher prep and student study days as well as homework pickup and delivery. Please mark your calendar with the following dates:

ul.li: May 4 - Learning resources delivery and work pickup
May 6 - Teacher prep day
March 8 - Homework pickup day
May 15 - Student study day and homework pickup
May 20 - Teacher prep day
May 22 - Homework pickup day

td.h3: Letter from District Administrator Teri Maney
td.p: The coronavirus pandemic has presented us all with some of the most challenging times we have ever encountered in public education. On Thursday, April 16, Governor Tony Evers announced all school buildings in Wisconsin will remain closed through the end of the 2019-20 school year which is June 30, 2020. This means the school buildings, grounds and facilities remain closed until that date. The Safer at Home order has been extended until 8 am, Tuesday, May 26 (or until a superseding order is issued). These two dates address separate circumstances and should not be confused with each other.

I know the school closure decision has caused a great deal of concern and disappointment for our students, families and staff. When we were first directed to close our school buildings in March, we did not realize it would be the last time we would see our students in person this school year. We are deeply saddened, but know safety is our No. 1 priority. Beating this virus and resuming school is the goal for each and every one of us, but at this time we know it will not be this school year. We will continue remote learning just as we have over the past several weeks. Our teachers and staff are doing their very best to keep quality instruction moving forward. They are teaching the prescribed and modified curriculum and addressing learning goals. Parents, we realize you are under a heavy burden as parent, teacher, caregiver and cheerleader. Students, continue to be your best and give your best as this work is preparing you for the future. It matters and counts! Our food service and paraprofessionals will continue to provide breakfast and lunches. Our bus service will continue to connect our community through food delivery and material drop off and pick up. A shout out to all of our parents, teachers, support services, and especially our students. YAHOO!!

Thank you for your patience and understanding as we work to bring answers regarding the end of the year, graduation and many other items. Please continue to stay safe and remain at home as much as possible. We greatly look forward to a time when it is safe to be with each other again.

sincerely.p: Sincerely,
Teri Maney
sincerely.h3: Daily Update for Three Lakes Schools
sincerely.p: Today, our admin team met to begin discussing plans for the remainder of the year. They are working on details for remote learning, graduation, awards ceremonies and more. Next week, expect to see a survey coming your way because we want to hear your opinions on some of these items. We'll have more information on that next week. Until then, rest assured that we are working hard to get everything in order and to have some answers for you on what the remainder of the year will look like. If you haven't yet, please watch this address from District Admininstrator Teri Maney as she shared her thoughts on the school closure announcement.
And, be sure to follow us on Facebook. We've started posting senior highlights to honor our class of 2020.
Have a great weekend, Bluejays! Rest up, and we'll "see" you again on Monday!
Three Lakes School District

Today, Gov. Evers updated the Safer at Home order, extending it to May 26. As part of that order, public schools will remain closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. However, remote learning will continue. We understand this is an unsettling announcement, so we'd like to share a message from District Administrator Teri Maney at this time:

From Ms. Maney: "Although our school building will be closed for the remainder of 2019-20, that does not mean education will stop. We will figure out the next few weeks and our instructional plans will move forward. We will continue to evolve in our instructional delivery. It means we are going to be creative, celebrate our seniors and come up with a graduation ceremony plan. Please understand this will take a little time to get in order, but we all will make this work. I have utmost faith in our students, staff and families. I am sad about this announcement today, but I am happy to be part of the Three Lakes family. We will rock this together!"
We will have more information to share with you in the days to come as we work out the details of this extended closure.

Hi, Bluejay Family! This is a sincere reminder that we truly care about all of you, and we wanted to let everyone know we are in this together. We understand that every student is a person and belongs to a family that has a unique set of challenges. We would like to lend a hand to anyone who needs academic, social or emotional support.

During this time, we would like to express our gratitude to everyone in the community who is actively assisting and helping each other out. We would also like to offer some mental health and wellness resources for students, parents, guardians and caregivers. Please take a look through this document, which we hope will be a resource during these challenging times.

Above and beyond the resources provided, please remember that our educators, counselors, administrators and every other school employee truly cares about you and your wellbeing. We all look forward to getting through this as one big Bluejay Family.
~ Ryan Bock

h3.span: Homework Drop Off Parent Email Alert

sincerely.p: On Friday, April 3, we will pick up homework from the first round of the closure. If you are on a bus route, a bus will stop at your house for pick up. We will also have drop-off boxes at the entrance of each school (Three Lakes Elementary, TL 7-12 and Sugar Camp), which anyone can use. Open-enroll students should drop off work at the school sites or contact their school secretary for pick up arrangements.

ul.li: The bus route will begin at 10 am on Friday.
Have your student's homework at the base of your mailbox by 10 am.
Put it in a plastic bag to protect it from the weather.
Label the bag with your student's name, grade and teacher name.

sincerely.p: The drop off boxes at the schools will be available from 9 am to 2 pm.
Your student's teacher will let you know which assignments should be returned. Library books may also be returned at this time if you are finished with them.

We will also run a drop off/pick up route on April 14. If your student is still working on material, it can be picked up on April 14 after break. During that run, we will distribute the next round of learning materials from your teachers.

ul.li: Busses pick up homework beginning at 10 am
Drop off boxes available at school from 9 am to 2 pm
Busses pick up homework and drop off new learning materials
Drop off boxes and pick up available at school from 9 am to 2 pm

h3.span: School Closure Schedule Change Parent Alert

sincerely.p: Good afternoon, Bluejays.
Our administrative team met yesterday to discuss the next phase of the school closure. You can watch an update from District Administror Teri Maney in this video.

This new schedule runs through the end of April, and includes several non-contact or teacher preparation days. These scheduled rest days will give us all a chance to catch our breath. We know everyone has been working so hard to make this a successful experience. We are also working on plans for homework pickup/dropoff days, which we will announce as we have more details. For now, please mark your calendar as follows:

ul.li: March 27 - Non-Contact Day (Students can catch up on homework or just rest. No new assignments or contact from teachers,)
April 1 - Teacher Prep Day
April 4-13 - Spring Break
April 22 - Teacher Prep Day
May 1 - Non-Contact Day

sincerely.p: How was your first remote learning day? We know you have many new routines to adjust to, so please contact us with any questions. Our teachers are working hard to stay connected to students and keep continuity in instruction.

Free meal delivery will begin on Monday, March 23. If you haven't already, please sign up on our Google form or call the district office at 715-546-3496. Each delivery will include a grab-and-go lunch as well as a breakfast for the next day. On Monday, you will receive two breakfasts and one lunch. Delivery routes will depart the school at 10 am. We also will have pickup locations at Three Lakes, Sugar Camp and Monico for our non-bus students. Pickup times are 11-11:20 at each location. Please see the attached fact sheet for more information on how the program will work.
And finally, the board meeting for tonight has been postponed. We've also been notified that the Demmer Library will be closing, beginning today.
We'll continue to provide updates for you each day of the closure. Watch your email in the afternoon around 2 pm.
Three Lakes School District
Good afternoon, parents/guardians.

Tomorrow begins the first day of remote learning for our students. Today, your student came home with instructions for what is expected of them over the next few weeks. We've also created a remote learning FAQ sheet for you, which is included with this email alert. In addition, elementary school plans and letters have been loaded to our website.
If you have any issues, please contact your buidling principal via email or by phone during office hours of 9 am to 2 pm.
This remains a very fluid situation, and we appreciate your patience and understanding as we work through unprecedented situations.
Three Lakes School District will be running a free meal program during the school closure. This program is available to all students and anyone under the age of 18 in your home.

If you are interested in signing up for the program, please fill out the Google form, call the school at 715-546-3496 or email kison@threelakessd.k12.wi.us. We are working on the details of the program and will share more as we have information available. For right now, we would just like to get a count of those interested.
Three Lakes School District

p.span: Good afternoon, Bluejays! We just wanted to touch base and remind you about this week's schedule in light of the upcoming state-mandated school closure.

sincerely.p: Tomorrow, Monday, March 16 - Students do not have school. All staff will report to work on virtual learning plans for the closure.
Tuesday, March 17 - All students and staff will report to school. Students will receive instructions for the closure and have a chance to meet with teachers and pick up computers and other items.
Wednesday, March 18 - First virtual learning day.

We cannot emphasize enough how fluid this situation remains. We'll be releasing more information in the coming days to answer your questions. We know that now, more than ever, the education of our students will be out of true partnership between parents, family, community and school staff. #BluejayCommunity

span.style: color: rgb(33, 84, 150); font-family: "EB Garamond", sans-serif; font-weight: 600; letter-spacing: 0px;

sincerely.p: This afternoon, Gov. Tony Evers mandated a statewide closure of all Wisconsin K-12 schools, public and private. The closure will run from Wednesday, March 18 through Monday, April 6.
Three Lakes School District will be open on Monday, March 16, and Tuesday, March 17. We will then close for March 18-April 6.
This is a very quickly moving situation, and we will have more information for you as decisions are made. For now, we wanted to communicate this closure information.
sincerely.h3: Address from District Administrator Teri Maney
sincerely.p: Dear Parents and Guardians:

The health, safety and well-being of our students and staff are our top priorities at the Three Lakes School District. With the recently elevated discussion regarding the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the news, we want to take a moment to reinforce preventive safety measures and reference our process and communications.

First, it is important to remember that at this time, there have only been a small number of confirmed cases of coronavirus in the United States. As a school district, we are closely monitoring the situation and following guidance from the Oneida County Health Department, the Wisconsin Department of Health, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction. We encourage our students, staff and families to be mindful of key preventive measures for any illness. The CDC offers some tips on its website that can be useful in avoiding the spread of coronavirus and other illnesses. We all play a role in reducing the likelihood of illness in our school-community. We encourage everyone to practice good habits including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, especially after using the restroom and before preparing or consuming food. Using soap and hot water wash for about 20 seconds. Be sure to also wash your fingertips.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don't have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.
If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Allow them some time to feel better so that they do not risk infecting others.

sincerely.p: If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me at 715/546-3496.
Sincerely,

Theresa Maney
District Administrator

address.a: 6930 West School Street, Three Lakes, WI 54562
